primary_factors: No accumulating snow or wintry precip signal in the provided forecast context (Sunday is cold/overcast and dry), so there’s no plowing catch-up problem for Monday morning
Wind chills are cold but nowhere near Michigan extreme-cold closure thresholds (no credible ≤-20°F signal for 6–8 AM bus hours)
Main roads/bus routes expected passable; only *localized* refreeze/black-ice risk on bridges, shaded rural connectors, and some neighborhood streets
No confirmed neighboring-district closure domino signals for Mon 2/23 as of Fri 2/20; Rockford PS has no closure/delay posting
Power-grid risk appears low: only scattered outages indicated systemwide after the Fri wind, unlikely to persist into Monday at disruptive levels
decision_rationale: Across meteorology, history, safety, news intel, infrastructure, and power-grid inputs, the base case for Rockford, MI on Mon 2/23 is a normal winter school day: no forecast accumulation, no ice event indicated, modest winds, and wind chills well above the -15°F/-20°F closure triggers. The only meaningful operational risk is *patchy* black ice from residual moisture/refreeze (bridges, shaded stretches, subdivisions), which in West Michigan typically leads to targeted treatment and cautious driving—more often a minor delay at most, not a districtwide closure. News/community signals do not show a closure trend in neighboring districts yet (appropriate this far out), and power-outage risk looks scattered and unlikely to force closure. What could make this wrong is an unmodeled late-Sunday-night band (lake-effect/clipper) or unexpected drizzle/fog deposition creating broader icing than expected—currently low-probability with the provided data.

collaboration.summary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 1.0% spread. Average probability: 4%.
